Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Hybrid zone formation and comparative genomic divergences in South American lizards (Iguania: Liolaemidae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hybrid zones are geographical areas where hybrid offspring have mixed genetic composition and physical appearances compared to their parent populations/species. By studying genomic divergence in hybrid zones, researchers can better understand which differences are responsible for the formation of new species, and also the genomic regions that separate species. Such knowledge is relevant to many fields beyond systematics, including ecology, conservation biology, and even agriculture. This research project focuses on species within the South American lizard genus, Liolaemus, and uses genomic tools to investigate the age of hybrid zones, how they form, and how natural and sexual selection maintain genetic boundaries. Although many hybrid zones have been studied in northern temperate systems, southern temperate systems have received comparatively little attention. This research will train one graduate student in diverse systematic methods and undergraduates in field, laboratory and analytical methods. The project will also enhance international scientific infrastructure through collaborations with Argentinian researchers. Results from this research will be broadly disseminated through displays and presentations at the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture in Seattle, WA.

The proposed research will investigate hybridization and comparative species divergences across three species pairs in the Liolaemus fitzingerii group. In part, the hypothesis will be tested that these hybrid zones have formed due to secondary contact following post-glacial range expansions approximately 12,000 years ago. Genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) data will be generated using the restriction site-associated DNA sequencing (RADseq) method to estimate the genetic and geographic transitions between species in three separate hybrid zones. SNP data will also be used to estimate evolutionary relationships and delimit species. Aligning the SNP data to an annotated genome will enable the identification of regions of the genome that are involved in maintaining species boundaries in this group. Together, these data will shed new light on the genomic changes that occur within hybrid zones, and provide novel insights into the mechanisms driving the formation of new species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many species diverge not in isolation but with some amountBottom of Form of genetic exchange with neighboring populations. With this grant, we intended to gain an understanding of the evolutionary relationships and hybridization dynamics between lizard species in the Liolaemus fitzingerii group. To understand hybridization, we must first understand the evolutionary history and relationships of species. Even when analyzing a relatively large portion of the genome, we recovered weak support for relationships between species. Our interpretation of this pattern is that all of the nine currently recognized species in this group evolved from a common ancestor in rapid succession, approximately 2-5 million years ago. Comparing two types of DNA (nuclear and mitochondrial) revealed hybridization between three species-pairs.

With a knowledge of which species appeared to be hybridizing, we conducted dense geographic sampling and studied three areas that marked the geographic interface between four populations. Our analyses revealed that two species, Liolaemus melanops and Liolaemus xanthoviridis, each hybridize with two other species. We estimated the strength of selection in these three hybrid zones, and discovered that selection is operating to different intensities in these three hybrid zones. This is interesting because in the case of L. melanops and L. xanthoviridis, we can begin to now ask questions that help us understand why selection works stronger when hybridizing with one species versus a different species. Just as in when determining species-level relationships, we compared the patterns of nuclear vs. mitochondrial DNA in these hybrid zones. In all three hybrid zones, the mitochondrial cline is shifted to the south of the nuclear cline. This indicates two interesting scenarios that could produce this pattern: 1) sex-biased dispersal where males are more likely to migrate northward across the hybrid zone than females, and/or 2) the populations, and therefore hybrid zones, are shifting to the north.

After gaining a deeper understanding of hybrid zone dynamics, we performed analyses to understand the population-level history of the species in this group to determine when, and potentially how, these populations came into contact. Studies of this nature, understanding how geographic features and past climatic fluctuations have affected organismal geographic distributions, are not common in southern South America. In spite of our current understanding of the Liolaemus fitzingerii species group that recognizes nine species, our genetic analyses identified six genetically distinct populations. These genetically distinct groups are delimited by large-scale geographic features in this region, such as wide rivers and mesas/plateaus. Modeling the demographic history of these populations revealed that each underwent a historic population expansion thousands of years ago, followed by a more recent population contraction. Interpreting this demographic history alongside estimates of genetic diversity indicate that these populations historically moved to the north and coastal areas, both of which are warmer than southern or inland regions, during cooler times in the past.

During this research, co-PI Grummer was able to live in Argentina for five months while conducting fieldwork. This allowed him a lot of contact time with the labs of his collaborators and a rich cultural immersion. Furthermore, he had many scientific discussions with locals during this time about herpetology and evolutionary biology. During these five months, he mentored two Brazilian undergraduate students as they completed independent research projects for their bachelor’s degrees. Additionally, he aided a graduate student in collecting research specimens from northwestern Argentina. Co-PI Grummer has broadly disseminated the research performed on this grant to international scientific audiences in Chile, Argentina, and China, the Young Naturalists’ Society, as well as the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture in Seattle, Washington.
